awd_titl_txt: Conference: Experimental Learning for Novel and Emerging Technologies (ExLENT) for Offshore Wind Energy Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Old Dominion University (ODU), partnered with Dominion Energy, Southeastern Wind Coalition, Hampton Roads Workforce Council (HRWC), and Centura College, proposes to collaborate with other regional industry and academia to host a one-day Offshore Wind Workforce Conference at ODU in Norfolk, Virginia in 2024. Keynote speakers from industry and academia will present and discuss current and forecasted offshore wind workforce and training needs and issues. Multiple subject matter expert panel discussions from industry and academia will discuss these and other important topics that are relevant to this industry, including: needed offshore wind workforce skillsets, STEM curriculum requirements, emerging trends in related technology, and research and development needs. 

This conference will be open to all traditional and non-traditional students at ODU as well as other regional training institutions and community colleges. A workforce development conference specifically focused on offshore wind will have significant positive impacts on regional companies, ODU students and faculty, and the community at large and will increase industry, academia, and government partnerships. It will also provide an opportunity for attendees to learn about the latest industry trends, technologies, best practices, and career opportunities. It will contribute to a workforce pipeline that promotes the participation of women, veterans, persons with disabilities, and underrepresented minorities. Attendees will be able to connect with potential employers, mentors, and peers, opening doors for collaboration, job opportunities, and partnerships.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Maritime and Offshore Wind Conference: Key Outcomes

On March 25, 2025, Old Dominion University (ODU), with support from the National Science Foundation (Award ID: 2347164), convened the Maritime and Offshore Wind Conference to address critical workforce and training needs in the offshore wind energy sector. With 340 registrants and approximately 275 attendees, the conference served as a collaborative forum for academia, industry, and government to shape the future of offshore wind workforce development, technology integration, and research collaboration.

Major Conference Outcomes

1. Workforce Development and Skills Alignment

A primary outcome of the conference was the identification and prioritization of essential workforce competencies for the offshore wind sector. Industry and academic experts emphasized both technical and soft skills critical for success. These included:

  • Technical: OSHA 10 and GWO safety certifications, engineering and construction knowledge, IT, logistics, and electrical systems.

  • Soft skills: Leadership, emotional intelligence, teamwork, adaptability, communication, ethics, and customer commitment.

Practical readiness, such as the ability to work at heights or on the water, and bilingualism were also valued. These insights directly inform curriculum alignment at educational institutions and help shape targeted training initiatives.

2. Student Engagement and Career Pathways

The conference provided students from ODU, community colleges, and high school maritime academies with invaluable networking opportunities. Panels, such as "Charting Careers in Offshore Wind" and "Employer Perspectives," offered real-world insights into career pathways, job expectations, and growth areas. Attendees learned about career options in engineering, marine coordination, IT, supply chain, cybersecurity, and business management.

Advice from industry leaders emphasized:

  • Seeking internships to gain experience.

  • Building strong, goal-oriented resumes.

  • Embracing continuous learning and being open to new roles.

  • Finding mentorship and defining personal success.

3. Research and Industry Collaboration

A key finding from post-conference surveys was strong mutual interest in academic–industry collaboration. Over one-third of industry attendees expressed interest in joint research with institutions, particularly in:

  • Turbine optimization

  • AI-driven health monitoring

  • Condition monitoring systems (CMS)

  • Cybersecurity for offshore infrastructure

These collaborations signal a strategic opportunity to integrate real-world challenges into research and classroom environments, advancing technological innovation while strengthening academia’s role in industry evolution.

4. Technological Innovation and Challenges

Panels and discussions spotlighted cutting-edge technologies, including:

  • AI for maintenance and predictive analytics.

  • Machine learning for extreme weather forecasting.

  • Digital twin systems for real-time turbine monitoring.

  • CMS sensors for turbine diagnostics.

Cybersecurity challenges were noted as a growing concern. Participants emphasized the importance of securing data flows and digital infrastructure supporting wind operations. The integration of Jones Act-compliant vessels for turbine transport and installation also emerged as a focal point for logistical innovation.

5. Stakeholder and Community Engagement

With participation from over 20 exhibitors and institutions—including Dominion Energy, Newport News Shipbuilding, the Virginia Maritime Association, and SUNY Maritime College—the conference successfully fostered broad community engagement. The event reinforced ODU’s leadership in maritime workforce development and established stronger academic-industry-government networks.

6. High Satisfaction and Next Steps

The conference received high marks from attendees, with a 9 out of 10 average rating. Notably, 97% of participants expressed interest in attending future events. Suggestions for next year included refining logistics, shortening the event for sharper focus, and expanding topics to include autonomous systems, port operations, and defense technologies.

7. Recommendations for Future Action

Based on conference insights, several strategic actions are recommended:

  • Curriculum Updates: Educational institutions should integrate feedback on soft skills, certifications, and hands-on training to align programs with real-world needs.

  • Expanded Internships: Broader collaboration between universities and employers is needed to offer diverse internship opportunities and mentorship programs.

  • Research Funding: Institutions should pursue funding for collaborative research in offshore wind innovation and infrastructure security.

  • Annual Conference Planning: Building on this year’s success, planning for an annual event can ensure continued momentum in workforce and research alignment.

The 2025 Maritime and Offshore Wind Conference has laid critical groundwork for advancing workforce development, research collaboration, and industry engagement in offshore wind energy. It marks a significant step forward in aligning educational programs with the dynamic needs of the energy transition, while opening career pathways for the next generation of maritime professionals.

 


Last Modified: 04/13/2025
Modified by: Elspeth McMahon

Maritime and Offshore Wind Conference: Key Outcomes


On March 25, 2025, Old Dominion University (ODU), with support from the National Science Foundation (Award ID: 2347164), convened the Maritime and Offshore Wind Conference to address critical workforce and training needs in the offshore wind energy sector. With 340 registrants and approximately 275 attendees, the conference served as a collaborative forum for academia, industry, and government to shape the future of offshore wind workforce development, technology integration, and research collaboration.
Major Conference Outcomes


1. Workforce Development and Skills Alignment


A primary outcome of the conference was the identification and prioritization of essential workforce competencies for the offshore wind sector. Industry and academic experts emphasized both technical and soft skills critical for success. These included:




Technical: OSHA 10 and GWO safety certifications, engineering and construction knowledge, IT, logistics, and electrical systems.




Soft skills: Leadership, emotional intelligence, teamwork, adaptability, communication, ethics, and customer commitment.




Practical readiness, such as the ability to work at heights or on the water, and bilingualism were also valued. These insights directly inform curriculum alignment at educational institutions and help shape targeted training initiatives.

Advice from industry leaders emphasized:

3. Research and Industry Collaboration


A key finding from post-conference surveys was strong mutual interest in academicindustry collaboration. Over one-third of industry attendees expressed interest in joint research with institutions, particularly in:

These collaborations signal a strategic opportunity to integrate real-world challenges into research and classroom environments, advancing technological innovation while strengthening academias role in industry evolution.


4. Technological Innovation and Challenges


Panels and discussions spotlighted cutting-edge technologies, including:




AI for maintenance and predictive analytics.

Cybersecurity challenges were noted as a growing concern. Participants emphasized the importance of securing data flows and digital infrastructure supporting wind operations. With participation from over 20 exhibitors and institutionsincluding Dominion Energy, Newport News Shipbuilding, the Virginia Maritime Association, and SUNY Maritime Collegethe conference successfully fostered broad community engagement. The event reinforced ODUs leadership in maritime workforce development and established stronger academic-industry-government networks.

The conference received high marks from attendees, with a 9 out of 10 average rating. Notably, 97% of participants expressed interest in attending future events. Suggestions for next year included refining logistics, shortening the event for sharper focus, and expanding topics to include autonomous systems, port operations, and defense technologies.


7. Recommendations for Future Action


Based on conference insights, several strategic actions are recommended:




Curriculum Updates: Educational institutions should integrate feedback on soft skills, certifications, and hands-on training to align programs with real-world needs.




Expanded Internships: Broader collaboration between universities and employers is needed to offer diverse internship opportunities and mentorship programs.

The 2025 Maritime and Offshore Wind Conference has laid critical groundwork for advancing workforce development, research collaboration, and industry engagement in offshore wind energy. It marks a significant step forward in aligning educational programs with the dynamic needs of the energy transition, while opening career pathways for the next generation of maritime professionals.
